Understanding Server-Assisted Federated Learning in the Presence of Incomplete Client Participation

Haibo Yang    Peiwen Qiu    Prashant Khanduri    Minghong Fang    Jia Liu
Abstract

Existing works in federated learning (FL) often assume an ideal system with either full client or uniformly distributed client participation. However, in practice, it has been observed that some clients may never participate in FL training (aka incomplete client participation) due to a myriad of system heterogeneity factors. A popular approach to mitigate impacts of incomplete client participation is the server-assisted federated learning (SA-FL) framework, where the server is equipped with an auxiliary dataset. However, despite SA-FL has been empirically shown to be effective in addressing the incomplete client participation problem, there remains a lack of theoretical understanding for SA-FL. Meanwhile, the ramifications of incomplete client participation in conventional FL are also poorly understood. These theoretical gaps motivate us to rigorously investigate SA-FL. Toward this end, we first show that conventional FL is not PAC-learnable under incomplete client participation in the worst case. Then, we show that the PAC-learnability of FL with incomplete client participation can indeed be revived by SA-FL, which theoretically justifies the use of SA-FL for the first time. Lastly, to provide practical guidance for SA-FL training under incomplete client participation, we propose the 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} (server-assisted federated averaging) algorithm that enjoys the same linear convergence speedup guarantees as classic FL with ideal client participation assumptions, offering the first SA-FL algorithm with convergence guarantee. Extensive experiments on different datasets show 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} significantly improves the performance under incomplete client participation.

Learning Theory, Federated Learning

1 Introduction

Since the seminal work by McMahan et al. (2017), federated learning (FL) has emerged as a powerful distributed learning paradigm that enables a large number of clients (e.g., edge devices) to collaboratively train a model under a central server’s coordination. However, as FL gaining popularity, it has also become apparent that FL faces a key challenge unseen in traditional distributed learning in data-center settings – system heterogeneity. Generally speaking, system heterogeneity in FL is caused by the massively different computation and communication capabilities at each client (computational power, communication capacity, drop-out rate, etc.). Studies have shown that system heterogeneity can significantly impact client participation in a highly non-trivial fashion and render incomplete client participation, which severely degrades the learning performance (Bonawitz et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2021a). For example, it is shown in (Yang et al., 2021a) that more than 30%percent3030\% clients never participate in FL, while only 30%percent3030\% of the clients contribute to 81%percent8181\% of the total computation even if the server uniformly samples the clients. Exacerbating the problem is the fact that clients’ status could be unstable and time-varying due to the aforementioned computation/communication constraints. This situation sharply contrasts with existing works on FL with partial client participation, which often assume that clients engage based on a known random process (Karimireddy et al., 2020; Malinovsky et al., 2023; Cho et al., 2023).

To mitigate the impact of incomplete client participation, one approach called server-assisted federated learning (SA-FL) has been widely adopted in real-world FL systems in recent years (see, e.g., (Zhao et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2021b)). The basic idea of SA-FL is to equip the server with a small auxiliary dataset sampled from population distribution, so that the distribution deviation induced by incomplete client participation can be corrected. Nonetheless, while SA-FL has empirically demonstrated its considerable efficacy in addressing incomplete client participation problem in practice, there remains a lack of theoretical understanding for SA-FL. This motivates us to rigorously investigate the efficacy of SA-FL in the presence of incomplete client participation.

Somewhat counterintuitively, to understand SA-FL, one must first fully understand the impact of incomplete client participation on conventional FL. In other words, we need to first answer the following fundamental question:

Upon answering this question, the next important follow-up question regarding SA-FL is:

Also, just knowing the benefits of SA-FL is not sufficient to provide guidelines on how to use server-side data in designing training algorithms with convergence guarantees. Therefore, our third fundamental question for SA-FL is:

Answering these three questions constitutes the rest of this paper, where we address Q1 and Q2 through the lens of PAC (probably approximately correct) learning, while resolving Q3 by proposing a provably convergent SA-FL algorithm. Our major contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    By establishing a worst-case generalization error lower bound, we rigorously show that classic FL is not PAC-learnable under incomplete client participation. In other words, no learning algorithm can approach zero generalization error with incomplete client participation for classic FL even in the limit of infinitely many data samples. This insight, though being negative, warrants the necessity of developing new algorithmic techniques and system architectures (e.g., SA-FL) to modify the classic FL framework to mitigate incomplete client participation.

  • •

    We prove a new generalization error bound to show that SA-FL can indeed revive the PAC learnability of FL with incomplete client participation. We note that this bound could reach zero asymptotically as the number data samples increases. This is much stronger than previous results in domain adaptation with non-vanishing small error (see Section 2 for details).

  • •

    To ensure that SA-FL is provably convergent in training, we propose a new training algorithm for SA-FL called 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} (server-assisted federated averaging). By carefully designing the server-client update coordination, we show that 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} achieves an 𝒪​(1/m​k​R)𝒪1𝑚𝑘𝑅\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{mkR}) convergence rate in non-convex functions and 𝒪~​(1R)~𝒪1𝑅\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{1}{R}) in strongly-convex functions, matching the convergence rates of state-of-the-art classic FL algorithms (Li et al., 2020b; Yang et al., 2021b). We also conduct extensive experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm.

2 Related Work

In this section, we provide an overview on two lines of closely related research, namely (i) FL with partial client participation and (ii) domain adaptation.

1) Partial Client Participation in Federated Learning: Since The seminal FedAvg algorithm (McMahan et al., 2017), there have been many follow-ups (e.g.,  (Li et al., 2020a; Wang et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2020; Acar et al., 2021; Karimireddy et al., 2020; Luo et al., 2021; Mitra et al., 2021; Karimireddy et al., 2021; Khanduri et al., 2021; Murata & Suzuki, 2021; Avdiukhin & Kasiviswanathan, 2021; Yang et al., 2021b; Grudzień et al., 2023; Condat et al., 2023; Mishchenko et al., 2022) and so on) on addressing the data heterogeneity challenge in FL. However, most of these works are based on the full or uniform (i.e., sampling clients uniformly at random) client participation assumption.

A related line of works in FL different from full/uniform client participation focuses on proactively creating flexible client participation (see, e.g., (Xie et al., 2019; Ruan et al., 2021; Gu et al., 2021; Avdiukhin & Kasiviswanathan, 2021; Yang et al., 2022; Wang & Ji, 2022; Koloskova et al., 2022)). The main idea here is to allow asynchronous communication or fixed participation pattern (e.g., given probability) for clients to flexibly participate in training. Existing works in this area often require extra assumptions, such as bounded delay (Ruan et al., 2021; Gu et al., 2021; Yang et al., 2022; Koloskova et al., 2022) and identical computation rate (Avdiukhin & Kasiviswanathan, 2021). Moreover, several papers explore unique scenarios of client participation. For instance, (Chen et al., 2020) selects the optimal client subset to minimize gradient estimation errors. The studies by (Malinovsky et al., 2023) and (Cho et al., 2023) investigated cyclic client participation. Additionally, in (Wang & Ji, 2023), optimal weights for each client are determined based on the estimated probabilities of their participation. In contrast, this paper addresses a more practical worst-case scenario in FL – “incomplete client participation.” This phenomenon may arise from various heterogeneous factors, as discussed in Section 1.

2) Domain Adaptation: Since incomplete client participation induces a gap between the dataset distribution used for FL training and the true data population distribution across all clients, our work is also related to the field of domain adaptation. Domain adaptation focuses on the learnability of a model trained in one source domain but applied to a different and related target domain. The basic approach is to quantify the error in terms of the source domain plus the distance between source and target domains. Specifically, let P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q be the target and source distributions, respectively. Then, the generalization error is expressed as 𝒪​(𝒜​(nQ))+d​i​s​t​(P,Q)𝒪𝒜subscript𝑛𝑄𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑃𝑄\mathcal{O}(\mathcal{A}(n_{Q}))+dist(P,Q), where 𝒜​(nQ)𝒜subscript𝑛𝑄\mathcal{A}(n_{Q}) is an upper bound of the error dependent on the total number of samples in Q𝑄Q. Widely-used distance measures include d𝒜subscript𝑑𝒜d_{\mathcal{A}}-divergence  (Ben-David et al., 2010; David et al., 2010) and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}-discrepancy  (Mansour et al., 2009; Mohri & Medina, 2012). We note, however, that results in domain adaptation is not directly applicable in FL with incomplete client participation, since doing so yields an overly pessimistic bound. Specifically, the error based on domain adaptation remains non-zero for asymptotically small distance d​i​s​t​(P,Q)𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑃𝑄dist(P,Q) between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q even with infinite many samples in nQsubscript𝑛𝑄n_{Q} (i.e., 𝒜​(nQ)→0→𝒜subscript𝑛𝑄0\mathcal{A}(n_{Q})\rightarrow 0). In this paper, rather than directly using results from domain adaptation, we establish a much sharper upper bound (see Section 3). A closely related work is (Hanneke & Kpotufe, 2019), which proposed a new notion of discrepancy between source and target distributions. However, this work considers non-overlapping support between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q, while we focus on overlapping support naturally implied by FL (see Fig. 1 in Section 3.2).

3 PAC-Learnability of Federated Learning with Incomplete Client Participation

In this section, we first focus on understanding the impacts of incomplete client participation on conventional FL in Section 3.1. This will also pave the way for studying SA-FL later in Section 3.2. In what follows, we start with FL formulation and some definitions in statistical learning that are necessary to formulate and prove our main results.

The goal of an M𝑀M-client FL system is to minimize the following loss function F​(𝐱)=𝔼i∼𝒫​[Fi​(𝐱)]𝐹𝐱subscript𝔼similar-to𝑖𝒫delimited-[]subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱F(\mathbf{x})=\mathbb{E}_{i\sim\mathcal{P}}[F_{i}(\mathbf{x})], where Fi​(𝐱)≜𝔼ξ∼Pi​[fi​(𝐱,ξ)]≜subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉subscript𝑃𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝜉F_{i}(\mathbf{x})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{\xi~{}\sim P_{i}}[f_{i}(\mathbf{x},\xi)]. Here, 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} represents the distribution of the entire client population, 𝐱∈ℝd𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the model parameter, Fi​(𝐱)subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱F_{i}(\mathbf{x}) represents the local loss function at client i𝑖i, and Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i} is the underlying distribution of the local dataset at client i𝑖i. In general, due to data heterogeneity, Pi≠Pjsubscript𝑃𝑖subscript𝑃𝑗P_{i}\neq P_{j} if i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. However, the loss function F​(𝐱)𝐹𝐱F(\mathbf{x}) or full gradient ∇F​(𝐱)∇𝐹𝐱\nabla F(\mathbf{x}) can not be directly computed since the exact distribution of data is unknown in general. Instead, one often considers the following empirical risk minimization (ERM) problem in the finite-sum form based on empirical risk F^​(𝐱)^𝐹𝐱\hat{F}(\mathbf{x}):

min𝐱∈ℝd⁡F^​(𝐱)≜∑i∈[M]αi​F^i​(𝐱),F^i​(𝐱)≜∑ξ∈Sifi​(𝐱,ξ),formulae-sequence≜subscript𝐱superscriptℝ𝑑^𝐹𝐱subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝛼𝑖subscript^𝐹𝑖𝐱≜subscript^𝐹𝑖𝐱subscript𝜉subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝐱𝜉\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\hat{F}(\mathbf{x})\triangleq\sum_{i\in[M]}\alpha_{i}\hat{F}_{i}(\mathbf{x}),\hat{F}_{i}(\mathbf{x})\triangleq\sum_{\xi\in S_{i}}f_{i}(\mathbf{x},\xi),

where Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is a local dataset at client i𝑖i with cardinality |Si|subscript𝑆𝑖|S_{i}|, whose samples are independently and identically sampled from distribution Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}, and αi=|Si|/(∑j∈[M]|Sj|)subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝑆𝑗\alpha_{i}=|S_{i}|/(\sum_{j\in[M]}|S_{j}|) (hence ∑i∈[M]αi=1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝛼𝑖1\sum_{i\in[M]}\alpha_{i}=1). For simplicity, we consider the balanced dataset case: αi=1/M,∀i∈[M]formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑖1𝑀for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑀\alpha_{i}={1}/{M},\forall i\in[M]. Next, we state several definitions from statistical learning (Mohri et al., 2018).

Definition 1 (Generalization and Empirical Errors).

Given a hypothesis h∈ℋℎℋh\in\mathcal{H}, a target concept f𝑓f, an underlying distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and a dataset S𝑆S i.i.d. sampled from 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} (S∼𝒟similar-to𝑆𝒟S\sim\mathcal{D}), the generalization error and empirical error of hℎh are defined as follows: ℛ𝒟​(h,f)=𝔼(x,y)∼𝒟​l​(h​(x),f​(x))subscriptℛ𝒟ℎ𝑓subscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝑦𝒟𝑙ℎ𝑥𝑓𝑥\mathcal{R}_{\mathcal{D}}(h,f)=\mathbb{E}_{(x,y)\sim\mathcal{D}}l(h(x),f(x)) and ℛ^D​(h,f)=(1/|S|)​∑i∈Sl​(h​(xi),f​(xi))subscript^ℛ𝐷ℎ𝑓1𝑆subscript𝑖𝑆𝑙ℎsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖\hat{\mathcal{R}}_{D}(h,f)=(1/|S|)\sum_{i\in S}l(h(x_{i}),f(x_{i})), where l​(⋅)𝑙⋅l(\cdot) is a valid loss function.

For simplicity, we will use ℛ𝒟​(h)subscriptℛ𝒟ℎ\mathcal{R}_{\mathcal{D}}(h) and ℛ^D​(h)subscript^ℛ𝐷ℎ\hat{\mathcal{R}}_{D}(h) for generalization and empirical errors and omit target concept f𝑓f.

Definition 2 (Optimal Hypothesis).

We define h𝒟∗=argminh∈ℋ​ℛ𝒟​(h)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝒟ℎℋargminsubscriptℛ𝒟ℎh_{\mathcal{D}}^{*}=\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\mathrm{argmin}}\mathcal{R}_{\mathcal{D}}(h) and h^𝒟∗=argminh∈ℋ​ℛ^𝒟​(h)superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝒟ℎℋargminsubscript^ℛ𝒟ℎ\hat{h}_{\mathcal{D}}^{*}=\underset{h\in\mathcal{H}}{\mathrm{argmin}}\hat{\mathcal{R}}_{\mathcal{D}}(h).

Definition 3 (Excess Error).

The excess error and excess empirical error are defined as ε𝒟​(h)=ℛ𝒟​(h)−ℛ𝒟​(h𝒟∗)subscript𝜀𝒟ℎsubscriptℛ𝒟ℎsubscriptℛ𝒟superscriptsubscriptℎ𝒟\varepsilon_{\mathcal{D}}(h)=\mathcal{R}_{\mathcal{D}}(h)-\mathcal{R}_{\mathcal{D}}(h_{\mathcal{D}}^{*}), and ε^𝒟​(h)=ℛ^𝒟​(h)−ℛ^𝒟​(h^𝒟∗)subscript^𝜀𝒟ℎsubscript^ℛ𝒟ℎsubscript^ℛ𝒟superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝒟\hat{\varepsilon}_{\mathcal{D}}(h)=\hat{\mathcal{R}}_{\mathcal{D}}(h)-\hat{\mathcal{R}}_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{h}_{\mathcal{D}}^{*}), respectively.

3.1 Conventional Federated Learning with Incomplete Client Participation

With the above notations, we now study conventional FL with incomplete client participation (Q1). Consider an FL system with M𝑀M clients in total. We let P𝑃P denote the underlying joint distribution of the entire system, which can be decomposed into the summation of the local distributions at each client, i.e., P=∑i∈[M]λi​Pi𝑃subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑃𝑖P=\sum_{i\in[M]}\lambda_{i}P_{i}, where λi>0subscript𝜆𝑖0\lambda_{i}>0 and ∑i∈[M]λi=1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑀subscript𝜆𝑖1\sum_{i\in[M]}\lambda_{i}=1. We assume that each client i𝑖i has n𝑛n training samples i.i.d. drawn from Pisubscript𝑃𝑖P_{i}, i.e., |Si|=n,∀i∈[M]formulae-sequencesubscript𝑆𝑖𝑛for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑀|S_{i}|=n,\forall i\in[M]. Then, S={(xi,yi),i∈[M×n]}𝑆subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑀𝑛S=\{(x_{i},y_{i}),i\in[M\times n]\} can be viewed as the dataset i.i.d. sampled from the joint distribution P𝑃P. We consider an incomplete client participation setting, where m∈[0,M)𝑚0𝑀m\in[0,M) clients participate in the FL training as a result of some client sampling/participation process ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. We let ℱ​(S)ℱ𝑆\mathcal{F}(S) represent the data ensemble actually used in training and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} denote the underlying distribution corresponding to ℱ​(S)ℱ𝑆\mathcal{F}(S). For convenience, we define the notion ω=mM𝜔𝑚𝑀\omega=\frac{m}{M} as the FL system capacity (i.e., only m𝑚m clients participate in the training). For FL with incomplete client participation, we establish the following fundamental performance limit of any FL learner in general. For simplicity, we use binary classification with zero-one loss here, but it is already sufficient to establish the PAC learnability lower limit.

Definition 4.

A concept class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} is said to be PAC learnable if there exists an algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and a polynomial function p​o​l​y​(⋅,⋅,⋅,⋅)𝑝𝑜𝑙𝑦⋅⋅⋅⋅poly(\cdot,\cdot,\cdot,\cdot) such that for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, and for any distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} over the instance space 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, the algorithm, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, outputs a hypothesis hℎh such that: ℙS∼D​(R​(hS)≤ϵ)≥1−δ,subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑆𝐷𝑅subscriptℎ𝑆italic-ϵ1𝛿\mathbb{P}_{S\sim D}(R(h_{S})\leq\epsilon)\geq 1-\delta, where R​(h)𝑅ℎR(h) denotes the generalization error of hypothesis hℎh returned by the algorithm. When such an algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} exists, it is called a PAC-learning algorithm for 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}.

In plain language, being PAC-learnable requires the hypothesis (or the model) returned by the algorithm after observing enough number of data samples is approximately correct (error at most ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) with high probability (at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta).

Theorem 1 (Impossibility Theorem).

Let ℋℋ\mathcal{H} be a non-trivial hypothesis space and ℒ:(𝒳,𝒴)(m×n)→ℋ:ℒ→superscript𝒳𝒴𝑚𝑛ℋ\mathcal{L}:(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{Y})^{(m\times n)}\rightarrow\mathcal{H} be the learner for an FL system. There exists a client participation process ℱℱ\mathcal{F} with FL system capacity ω𝜔\omega, a distribution P𝑃P, and a target concept f∈ℋ𝑓ℋf\in\mathcal{H} with minh∈ℋ⁡ℛP​(h,f)=0subscriptℎℋsubscriptℛ𝑃ℎ𝑓0\min_{h\in\mathcal{H}}\mathcal{R}_{P}(h,f)=0, such that ℙS∼P​[ℛP​(ℒ​(ℱ​(S),f))>1−ω8]>120subscriptℙsimilar-to𝑆𝑃delimited-[]subscriptℛ𝑃ℒℱ𝑆𝑓1𝜔8120\mathbb{P}_{S\sim P}\big{[}\mathcal{R}_{P}(\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{F}(S),f))>\frac{1-\omega}{8}\big{]}>\frac{1}{20}.

Proof Sketch.

The proof is based on the method of induced distributions in (Bshouty et al., 2002; Mohri et al., 2018; Konstantinov et al., 2020). We first show that the learnability of an FL system is equivalent to that of a system that arbitrarily selects m​n𝑚𝑛mn out of M​n𝑀𝑛Mn samples in the centralized learning. Then, for any learning algorithm, there exists a distribution P𝑃P such that dataset ℱ​(S)ℱ𝑆\mathcal{F}(S) resulting from incomplete participation and seen by the algorithm is always distributed identically for any target functions. Due to space limitation, we relegate the full proof to appendix. ∎

Given the system capacity ω∈(0,1)𝜔01\omega\in(0,1), the above theorem characterizes the worst-case scenario for FL with incomplete client participation. It says that for any learner (i.e., algorithm) ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, there exist a bad client participation process ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and distributions Pi,i∈[M]subscript𝑃𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑀P_{i},i\in[M] over target function f𝑓f, for which the error of the hypotheses returned by ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is constant with non-zero probability. In other words, FL with incomplete client participation is not PAC-learnable. One interesting observation here is that the lower bound is independent of the number of samples per client n𝑛n. This indicates that even if each client has infinitely many samples (n→∞→𝑛n\rightarrow\infty), it is impossible to have a zero-generation-error learner under the incomplete client participation (i.e., ω∈(0,1)𝜔01\omega\in(0,1)). Note that this fundamental result relies on two conditions: heterogeneous dataset and arbitrary client participation. Under these two conditions, there exists a worst-case scenario where the underlying distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of the participating data S𝒟=ℱ​(S)subscript𝑆𝒟ℱ𝑆S_{\mathcal{D}}=\mathcal{F}(S) deviates from the ground truth P𝑃P, thus yielding a non-vanishing error.

This result sheds light on system and algorithm design for FL. That is, how to motivate client participation in FL effectively and efficiently: the participating client’s data should be comprehensive enough to model the complexity of the joint distribution P𝑃P to close the gap between 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} and P𝑃P. Note that this result is not contradictory to previous works where the convergence of FedAvg is guaranteed, since this theorem is not applicable for homogeneous (i.i.d.) datasets or uniformly random client participation. As mentioned earlier, most of the existing works rely on at least one of these two assumptions. However, none of these two assumptions hold for conventional FL with incomplete client participation in practice. In addition to system heterogeneity, other factors such as Byzantine attackers could also render incomplete client participation. For example, even for full client participation in FL, if part of the clients are Byzantine attackers, the impossibility theorem also applies. Thus, our impossibility theorem also justifies the empirical use of server-assisted federated learning (i.e., FL with server-side auxiliary data) to build trust (Cao et al., 2021).

3.2 The PAC-Learnability of Server-Assisted Federated Learning (SA-FL)

The intuition of SA-FL is to utilize a dataset T𝑇T i.i.d. sampled from distribution P𝑃P with cardinality |T|=nT𝑇subscript𝑛𝑇|T|=n_{T} as a vehicle to correct potential distribution deviations due to incomplete client participation. By doing so, the server steers the learning by a small number of representative data, while the clients assist the learning by federation to leverage the huge amount of privately decentralized data (nS≫nTmuch-greater-thansubscript𝑛𝑆subscript𝑛𝑇n_{S}\gg n_{T}).

For SA-FL, we consider the same incomplete client participation setting that induces a dataset S𝒟∼𝒟similar-tosubscript𝑆𝒟𝒟S_{\mathcal{D}}\sim\mathcal{D} with cardinality nSsubscript𝑛𝑆n_{S} and 𝒟≠P𝒟𝑃\mathcal{D}\neq P (i.e., Q2). As a result, the learning process is to minimize ℛP​(h)subscriptℛ𝑃ℎ\mathcal{R}_{P}(h) by utilizing (𝒳,𝒴)nT+nSsuperscript𝒳𝒴subscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑆(\mathcal{X},\mathcal{Y})^{n_{T}+n_{S}} to learn a hypothesis h∈ℋℎℋh\in\mathcal{H}. For notional clarity, we assume the joint dataset SQ=(S𝒟∪T)∼Qsubscript𝑆𝑄subscript𝑆𝒟𝑇similar-to𝑄S_{Q}=(S_{\mathcal{D}}\cup T)\sim Q with cardinality nT+nSsubscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑆n_{T}+n_{S} for some distribution Q𝑄Q. Before deriving the generalization error bound for SA-FL, we state the following assumptions and definitions.

Assumption 1 (Noise Condition).

Suppose hP∗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑃h_{P}^{*} and hQ∗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑄h_{Q}^{*} exist. There exist βP,βQ∈[0,1]subscript𝛽𝑃subscript𝛽𝑄01\beta_{P},\beta_{Q}\in[0,1] and αP,αQ>0subscript𝛼𝑃subscript𝛼𝑄0\alpha_{P},\alpha_{Q}>0 s.t., ℙx∼P​(h​(x)≠hP∗​(x))≤αP​[εP​(h)]βPsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝑥𝑃ℎ𝑥superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑃𝑥subscript𝛼𝑃superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜀𝑃ℎsubscript𝛽𝑃\mathbb{P}_{x\sim P}(h(x)\neq h_{P}^{*}(x))\leq\alpha_{P}[\varepsilon_{P}(h)]^{\beta_{P}}, ℙx∼Q​(h​(x)≠hQ∗​(x))≤αq​[εQ​(h)]βQsubscriptℙsimilar-to𝑥𝑄ℎ𝑥superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑄𝑥subscript𝛼𝑞superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜀𝑄ℎsubscript𝛽𝑄\mathbb{P}_{x\sim Q}(h(x)\neq h_{Q}^{*}(x))\leq\alpha_{q}[\varepsilon_{Q}(h)]^{\beta_{Q}}.

This assumption is a traditional noise model known as the Bernstein class condition, which has been widely used in the literature (Massart & Nédélec, 2006; Koltchinskii, 2006; Hanneke, 2016).

Assumption 2 ((α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-Positively-Related).

Distributions P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q are said to be (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-positively-related if there exist constants α≥0𝛼0\alpha\geq 0 and β≥0𝛽0\beta\geq 0 such that |εP​(h)−εQ​(h)|≤α​[εQ​(h)]β,∀h∈ℋformulae-sequencesubscript𝜀𝑃ℎsubscript𝜀𝑄ℎ𝛼superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜀𝑄ℎ𝛽for-allℎℋ|\varepsilon_{P}(h)-\varepsilon_{Q}(h)|\leq\alpha[\varepsilon_{Q}(h)]^{\beta},\forall h\in\mathcal{H}.

Assumption 2 specifies a stronger constraint between distributions P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q. It implies that the difference of excess error for one hypothesis h∈ℋℎℋh\in\mathcal{H} between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q is bounded by the excess error of Q𝑄Q in some exponential form. Assumption 2 is one of the major novelty in our paper and unseen in the literature. We note that this (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-positively-related condition is a mild condition. To see this, consider the following “one-dimensional” example for simplicity. Let ℋℋ\mathcal{H} be the class of hypotheses defined on the real line: {ht=t,t∈R}formulae-sequencesubscriptℎ𝑡𝑡𝑡𝑅\{h_{t}=t,t\in R\}, and let two uniform distributions be P:=𝒰​[a,b]assign𝑃𝒰𝑎𝑏P:=\mathcal{U}[a,b] and Q:=𝒰​[a′,b′]assign𝑄𝒰superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′Q:=\mathcal{U}[a^{\prime},b^{\prime}]. Due to the incomplete client sampling in FL, the support of Q𝑄Q is a subset of that of P𝑃P, i.e., a≤a′≤b′≤b𝑎superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′𝑏a\leq a^{\prime}\leq b^{\prime}\leq b. Denote the target hypothesis t∗∈[a′,b′]superscript𝑡superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′t^{*}\in[a^{\prime},b^{\prime}]. Then, for any hypothesis htsubscriptℎ𝑡h_{t} with threshold t𝑡t, we have ϵP​(ht)=|t−t∗|b−asubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑃subscriptℎ𝑡𝑡superscript𝑡𝑏𝑎\epsilon_{P}(h_{t})=\frac{|t-t^{*}|}{b-a} and ϵQ​(ht)=|t−t∗|b′−a′subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄subscriptℎ𝑡𝑡superscript𝑡superscript𝑏′superscript𝑎′\epsilon_{Q}(h_{t})=\frac{|t-t^{*}|}{b^{\prime}-a^{\prime}}. That is, our "(α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-Positively-Related" holds for α=1−b′−a′b−a𝛼1superscript𝑏′superscript𝑎′𝑏𝑎\alpha=1-\frac{b^{\prime}-a^{\prime}}{b-a} and β=1𝛽1\beta=1. The above “one-dimensional” example can be further extended to general high-dimensional cases as follows. Intuitively, the difference of excess errors of P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q (i.e., |ϵP​(h)−ϵQ​(h)|subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑃ℎsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑄ℎ|\epsilon_{P}(h)-\epsilon_{Q}(h)|) is a function in the form of ∫S|QX−PX|​𝑑Ssubscript𝑆subscript𝑄𝑋subscript𝑃𝑋differential-d𝑆\int_{S}|Q_{X}-P_{X}|dS for a common support domain S⊂s​u​p​p​(Q)𝑆𝑠𝑢𝑝𝑝𝑄S\subset supp(Q). Thus, the “(α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-Positively-Related” condition can be written as |∫SQX​𝑑S−∫SPX​𝑑S|≤α​(∫SQX)βsubscript𝑆subscript𝑄𝑋differential-d𝑆subscript𝑆subscript𝑃𝑋differential-d𝑆𝛼superscriptsubscript𝑆subscript𝑄𝑋𝛽|\int_{S}Q_{X}dS-\int_{S}P_{X}dS|\leq\alpha(\int_{S}Q_{X})^{\beta}. If distribution Q𝑄Q has more probability mass over S𝑆S than distribution P𝑃P, choosing β=1𝛽1\beta=1 and α𝛼\alpha to be a sufficiently large constant clearly satisfies the (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-positively-related condition. Otherwise, letting β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0 and choosing α𝛼\alpha to be a sufficiently large constant satisfies the (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-positively-related condition with probability one.

With the above assumption and definition, we have the following generation error bound for SA-FL, which shows that SA-FL is PAC-learnable:

Theorem 2 (Generalization Error Bound for SA-FL).

For an SA-FL system with arbitrary system and data heterogeneity, if distributions P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q satisfy Assumption 1 and 2, then with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta for any δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), it holds that

εP​(h^Q∗)=𝒪~​((dℋnT+nS)12−βQ+(dℋnT+nS)β2−βQ),subscript𝜀𝑃superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑄~𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑑ℋsubscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑆12subscript𝛽𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑑ℋsubscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑆𝛽2subscript𝛽𝑄\displaystyle\varepsilon_{P}(\hat{h}_{Q}^{*})\!\!=\!\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\left(\frac{d_{\mathcal{H}}}{n_{T}+n_{S}}\right)^{\frac{1}{2-\beta_{Q}}}\!\!\!\!\!\!\!+\!\!\left(\frac{d_{\mathcal{H}}}{n_{T}+n_{S}}\right)^{\frac{\beta}{2-\beta_{Q}}}\right), (1)

where dℋsubscript𝑑ℋd_{\mathcal{H}} is the finite VC dimension for hypotheses class ℋℋ\mathcal{H}.

Note the generalization error bound of centralized learning is 𝒪~​((dℋn)12−βQ)~𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑑ℋ𝑛12subscript𝛽𝑄\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}((\frac{d_{\mathcal{H}}}{n})^{\frac{1}{2-\beta_{Q}}}) (hiding logarithmic factors) with n𝑛n samples in total and noise parameter βQsubscript𝛽𝑄\beta_{Q} (Hanneke, 2016). Note that when β≥1𝛽1\beta\geq 1, the first term in Eq. (1) dominates. Hence, Theorem 2 implies that the generalization error bound in this case for SA-FL matches that of centralized learning (with dataset size nT+nSsubscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑆n_{T}+n_{S}). Meanwhile, for 0<β<10𝛽10<\beta<1, compared with solely training on server’s dataset T𝑇T, SA-FL exhibits an improvement from 𝒪~​((1nT)12−βQ)~𝒪superscript1subscript𝑛𝑇12subscript𝛽𝑄\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}((\frac{1}{n_{T}})^{\frac{1}{2-\beta_{Q}}}) to 𝒪~​((1nT+nS)β2−βQ)~𝒪superscript1subscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑆𝛽2subscript𝛽𝑄\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}((\frac{1}{n_{T}+n_{S}})^{\frac{\beta}{2-\beta_{Q}}}).

Note that SA-FL shares some similarity with the domain adaptation problem, where the learning is on Q𝑄Q but the results will be adapted to P𝑃P. In what follows, we offer some deeper insights between the two by answering two key questions: 1) What is the difference between SA-FL and domain adaptation (or transfer learning)? and 2) Why is SA-FL from Q𝑄Q to P𝑃P PAC-learnable, but FL from D𝐷D to P𝑃P with incomplete client participation not PAC-learnable (as indicated in Theorem 1)?

To answer these questions, we illustrate the distribution relationships for domain adaptation and federated learning, in Fig. 1, respectively. In domain adaptation, the target P𝑃P and source Q𝑄Q distributions often have overlapping support but there also exists distinguishable difference. In contrast, the two distributions P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q in SA-FL happen to share exactly the same support with different density, since Q𝑄Q is a mixture of D𝐷D and P𝑃P. As a result, the known bounds in domain adaptation (or transfer learning) are pessimistic for SA-FL. For example, the d​i​s​t​(P,Q)𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑃𝑄dist(P,Q) in d𝒜subscript𝑑𝒜d_{\mathcal{A}}-divergence and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}-divergence both have non-negligible gaps when applied to SA-FL. Here in Theorem 2, we provide a generalization error bound in terms of the total sample size nT+nSsubscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑆n_{T}+n_{S}, thus showing the benefit of SA-FL.

Moreover, for SA-FL, only the auxiliary dataset T​∼i.i.d.​PT\overset{i.i.d.}{\sim}P is directly available to the server. The clients’ datasets could be used in SA-FL training, but they are not directly accessible due to privacy constraints. Thus, previous methods in domain adaptation (e.g., importance weights-based methods in covariate shift adaptation (Sugiyama et al., 2007a, b)) are not applicable since they require the knowledge of density ratio between training and test datasets.

The key difference between FL and SA-FL lies in relations among D,P𝐷𝑃D,P and Q𝑄Q. For FL, the distance between D𝐷D and P𝑃P with incomplete participation could be large due to system and data heterogeneity in the worst-case. More specifically, the support of D𝐷D could be narrow enough to miss some part of P𝑃P, resulting in non-vanishing error as indicated in Theorem 1. For SA-FL, distribution Q𝑄Q is a mixture of P𝑃P and D𝐷D (Q=λ1​D+λ2​P𝑄subscript𝜆1𝐷subscript𝜆2𝑃Q=\lambda_{1}D+\lambda_{2}P, with λ1,λ2≥0subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆20\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}\geq 0, λ1+λ2=1subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆21\lambda_{1}+\lambda_{2}=1), thus having the same support with P𝑃P. Hence, under Assumption 2, the PAC-learnability is guaranteed. Although we provide a promising bound to show the PAC-learnability of SA-FL in Theorem 2, the superiority of SA-FL over training solely with dataset T𝑇T in server (i.e., 𝒪~​((1nT)12−βP)~𝒪superscript1subscript𝑛𝑇12subscript𝛽𝑃\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}((\frac{1}{n_{T}})^{\frac{1}{2-\beta_{P}}})) is not always guaranteed as β→0→𝛽0\beta\rightarrow 0 (i.e., Q𝑄Q becomes increasingly different from P𝑃P). In what follows, we reveal under what conditions could SA-FL perform no worse than centralized learning.

Theorem 3 (Conditions of SA-FL Being No Worse Than Centralized Learning).

Consider an SA-FL system with arbitrary system and data heterogeneity. If Assumption 1 holds and additionally ℛ^P​(h^Q∗)≤ℛ^P​(hQ∗)subscript^ℛ𝑃superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑄subscript^ℛ𝑃superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑄\mathcal{\hat{R}}_{P}(\hat{h}_{Q}^{*})\leq\mathcal{\hat{R}}_{P}(h_{Q}^{*}) and εP​(hQ∗)=𝒪​(𝒜​(nT,δ))subscript𝜀𝑃superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑄𝒪𝒜subscript𝑛𝑇𝛿\varepsilon_{P}(h_{Q}^{*})=\mathcal{O}(\mathcal{A}(n_{T},\delta)), where 𝒜​(nT,δ)=dℋnT​log⁡(nTdℋ+1nT​log⁡(1δ))𝒜subscript𝑛𝑇𝛿subscript𝑑ℋsubscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑛𝑇subscript𝑑ℋ1subscript𝑛𝑇1𝛿\mathcal{A}(n_{T},\delta)=\frac{d_{\mathcal{H}}}{n_{T}}\log(\frac{n_{T}}{d_{\mathcal{H}}}+\frac{1}{n_{T}}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})), then with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta for any δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), it holds that εP​(h^Q∗)=𝒪~​((dℋ/nT)12−βP)subscript𝜀𝑃superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑄~𝒪superscriptsubscript𝑑ℋsubscript𝑛𝑇12subscript𝛽𝑃\varepsilon_{P}(\hat{h}_{Q}^{*})=\widetilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(\left(d_{\mathcal{H}}/n_{T}\right)^{\frac{1}{2-\beta_{P}}}\right).

Here, we remark that εP​(hQ∗)=𝒪​(𝒜​(nT,δ))subscript𝜀𝑃superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑄𝒪𝒜subscript𝑛𝑇𝛿\varepsilon_{P}(h_{Q}^{*})=\mathcal{O}(\mathcal{A}(n_{T},\delta)) is a weaker condition than the εP​(hQ∗)=0subscript𝜀𝑃superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑄0\varepsilon_{P}(h_{Q}^{*})=0 condition and the covariate shift assumption (PY|X=QY|Xsubscript𝑃conditional𝑌𝑋subscript𝑄conditional𝑌𝑋P_{Y|X}=Q_{Y|X}) used in the transfer learning literatures (Hanneke & Kpotufe, 2019, 2020). Together with the condition ℛ^P​(h^Q∗)≤ℛ^P​(hQ∗)subscript^ℛ𝑃superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑄subscript^ℛ𝑃superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑄\mathcal{\hat{R}}_{P}(\hat{h}_{Q}^{*})\leq\mathcal{\hat{R}}_{P}(h_{Q}^{*}), the following intermediate result holds: ℛ^P​(h^Q∗)−ℛ^P​(hP∗)=𝒪​(A​(nT,δ))subscript^ℛ𝑃superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑄subscript^ℛ𝑃superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑃𝒪𝐴subscript𝑛𝑇𝛿\mathcal{\hat{R}}_{P}(\hat{h}_{Q}^{*})-\mathcal{\hat{R}}_{P}(h_{P}^{*})=\mathcal{O}(A(n_{T},\delta)) (see Lemma 2 in the supplementary material). Intuitively, this states that “if P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q share enough similarity, then the difference of excess empirical error between h^Q∗superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑄\hat{h}_{Q}^{*} and hP∗superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑃h_{P}^{*} on P𝑃P can be bounded.” Thus, the excess error of h^Q∗superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑄\hat{h}_{Q}^{*} shares the same upper bound as that of h^P∗superscriptsubscript^ℎ𝑃\hat{h}_{P}^{*} in centralized learning. Therefore, Theorem 3 implies that, under mild conditions, SA-FL guarantees the same generalization error upper bound as that of centralized learning, hence being “no worse than” centralized learning with dataset T𝑇T.

Remark 1.

Note that the assumption of having a server-side dataset is not restrictive due to the following reasons. First, such datasets are already available in many FL systems: although not always necessary for training, an auxiliary dataset is often needed for defining FL tasks (e.g., simulation prototyping) before training and model checking after training (e.g., quality evaluation and sanity checking) (McMahan et al., 2021; Wang et al., 2021a). Also, obtaining an auxiliary dataset is affordable since the number of data points required is relatively small, and hence the cost is low. Then, SA-FL can be easily achieved or even with manually labelled data thanks to its small size. It is also worth noting that many works have used such auxiliary datasets in FL for security (Cao et al., 2021), incentive design  (Wang et al., 2019), and knowledge distillation  (Cho et al., 2021).

Remark 2.

It is also worth pointing out that, for ease of illustration, Theorem 2–3 are based on the assumption that the auxiliary dataset T​∼i.i.d.​PT\overset{i.i.d.}{\sim}P. Nonetheless, it is of practical importance to consider the scenario where T𝑇T is sampled from a related but slightly different distribution P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} rather than the target distribution P𝑃P itself. In fact, the above assumption could be relaxed to T​∼i.i.d.​P′T\overset{i.i.d.}{\sim}P^{{}^{\prime}} for any P′superscript𝑃′P^{\prime} as long as the mixture distribution Q=λ1​D+λ2​P′𝑄subscript𝜆1𝐷subscript𝜆2superscript𝑃′Q=\lambda_{1}D+\lambda_{2}P^{\prime} is (α,β)𝛼𝛽(\alpha,\beta)-positively-related with P𝑃P. Under such condition, we can show that the main results in Theorem 2–3 still hold.

4 The 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} Algorithm for SA-FL

In Section 3, we have shown that SA-FL is PAC-learnable with incomplete client participation. In this section, we turn our attention to the training of the SA-FL regime with incomplete client participation (i.e., Q3), which is also under-explored in the literature. First, we note that the standard FedAvg algorithm may fail to converge to a stationary point with incomplete client participation as indicated by previous works (Yang et al., 2022). Now with SA-FL, we aim to answer the following questions:

  • 1)

    Under SA-FL, how should we appropriately use the server-side dataset to develop training algorithms in the SA-FL regime with provable convergence guarantees?

  • 2)

    If Question 1) can be resolved, could we further achieve the same convergence rate in SA-FL training with incomplete client participation as that in traditional FL with ideal client participation?

In this section, we resolve the above questions affirmatively by proposing a new algorithm called 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} (server-assisted federated averaging) for SA-FL with theoretically provable convergence guarantees. As shown in Algorithm 1, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} contains two options in each round, client update option or global server update option. For a communication round r∈{0,⋯,R−1}𝑟0⋯𝑅1r\in\{0,\cdots,R-1\}, with probability q∈[0,1]𝑞01q\in[0,1], the client update option is chosen (i.e., r∈𝒯c𝑟subscript𝒯𝑐r\in\mathcal{T}_{c}), where local updates are executed by clients in the current participating client set Srsubscript𝑆𝑟S_{r} in a similar fashion as the FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017). Specifically, the client update option performs the following three steps: 1) Server samples a subset of clients Srsubscript𝑆𝑟S_{r} as in conventional FL and synchronizes the latest global model 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} with each participating clients in Srsubscript𝑆𝑟S_{r} (Line 4); 2) All participating clients initialize their local models as 𝐱rsubscript𝐱𝑟\mathbf{x}_{r} and then perform K𝐾K local steps following the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) method. Then, each participating client sends its locally updated model 𝐱ri=𝐱r,K+1isuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑟𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑟𝐾1𝑖\mathbf{x}_{r}^{i}=\mathbf{x}_{r,K+1}^{i} back to the server (Lines 5-8); 3) Upon receiving the local update 𝐱risuperscriptsubscript𝐱𝑟𝑖\mathbf{x}_{r}^{i}, the server aggregates and updates the global model (Line 9). On the other hand, with probability 1−q1𝑞1-q, the server update option is chosen (i.e,. r∈𝒯s𝑟subscript𝒯𝑠r\in\mathcal{T}_{s}), where the server updates the global model with its auxiliary data following the SGD (Line 11).

We note that 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} can be viewed as a mixture of the FedAvg algorithm with client-side datasets (cf. the client update option) and a centralized SGD algorithm using the server-side dataset only (cf. the server update option), which are governed by a probability parameter q𝑞q. The basic idea of this two-option approach is to leverage client-side parallel computing to accelerate the training process, while using the server-side dataset to mitigate the bias caused by incomplete client participation. We will show later that, by appropriately choosing the q𝑞q-value, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} simultaneously achieves the stationary point convergence and linear convergence speedup. Before presenting the convergence performance results, we first state three commonly used assumptions in FL.

Assumption 3.

(L𝐿L-Lipschitz Continuous Gradient) There exists a constant L>0𝐿0L>0, such that ‖∇Fi​(𝐱)−∇Fi​(𝐲)‖≤L​‖𝐱−𝐲‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐲𝐿norm𝐱𝐲\|\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{y})\|\leq L\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\|, ∀i∈[M],𝐱,𝐲∈ℝdformulae-sequencefor-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑀𝐱𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑\forall i\in[M],\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Assumption 4.

(Unbiased Stochastic Gradients with Bounded Variance) The stochastic gradient calculated by the client or server is unbiased with bounded variance: for server, 𝔼​[∇F​(𝐱,ξ)]=∇F​(𝐱)𝔼delimited-[]∇𝐹𝐱𝜉∇𝐹𝐱\mathbb{E}[\nabla F(\mathbf{x},\xi)]=\nabla F(\mathbf{x}) and 𝔼​[‖∇F​(𝐱,ξ)−∇F​(𝐱)‖2]≤σs2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐹𝐱𝜉∇𝐹𝐱2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x},\xi)-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma_{s}^{2}; for each client i∈[M]𝑖delimited-[]𝑀i\in[M], 𝔼​[∇Fi​(𝐱,ξ)]=∇Fi​(𝐱)𝔼delimited-[]∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱𝜉∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱\mathbb{E}[\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x},\xi)]=\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x}), and 𝔼​[‖∇Fi​(𝐱,ξ)−∇Fi​(𝐱)‖2]≤σ2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱𝜉∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱2superscript𝜎2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x},\xi)-\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}.

Assumption 5.

(Bounded Gradient Dissimilarity) ‖∇Fi​(𝐱)−∇F​(𝐱)‖2≤σG2,∀i∈[M]formulae-sequencesuperscriptnorm∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐱∇𝐹𝐱2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺2for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑀\|\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{G}^{2},\forall i\in[M].

With the assumptions above, we state the main convergence result of 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} for non-convex functions as follows:

Theorem 4 (Convergence Rate for 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} in Non-Convex Functions).

Under Assumptions 3 -  5, if ηc≤14​30​L​Ksubscript𝜂𝑐1430𝐿𝐾\eta_{c}\leq\frac{1}{4\sqrt{30}LK}, ηc=2​ηsKsubscript𝜂𝑐2subscript𝜂𝑠𝐾\eta_{c}=\frac{2\eta_{s}}{K}, and q≤1/(4​σG2−4​G2​(12​K2−2​L​ηs2K2)(1−L​ηs)​G1+1)𝑞14superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺24subscript𝐺212superscript𝐾22𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑠2superscript𝐾21𝐿subscript𝜂𝑠subscript𝐺11q\leq 1/\left(\frac{4\sigma_{G}^{2}-4G_{2}(\frac{1}{2K^{2}}-\frac{2L\eta_{s}^{2}}{K^{2}})}{(1-L\eta_{s})G_{1}}+1\right), then, the sequence {𝐱r}subscript𝐱𝑟\{\mathbf{x}_{r}\} generated by 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} satisfies:

1R​∑r=1R𝔼​‖∇F​(𝐱r)‖2≤2​(F​(𝐱0)−F​(𝐱∗))R​ηs+δ,1𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑟1𝑅𝔼superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑟22𝐹subscript𝐱0𝐹superscript𝐱𝑅subscript𝜂𝑠𝛿\displaystyle\frac{1}{R}\sum_{r=1}^{R}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{r})\|^{2}\leq\frac{2(F(\mathbf{x}_{0})-F(\mathbf{x}^{*}))}{R\eta_{s}}+\delta,

where δ=L​ηs​(1−q)​σs2+80​q​L2​ηs2K​(σ2+6​K​σG2)+8​L​q​ηsm​K​σ2𝛿𝐿subscript𝜂𝑠1𝑞superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠280𝑞superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑠2𝐾superscript𝜎26𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺28𝐿𝑞subscript𝜂𝑠𝑚𝐾superscript𝜎2\delta=L\eta_{s}(1-q)\sigma_{s}^{2}+\frac{80qL^{2}\eta_{s}^{2}}{K}(\sigma^{2}+6K\sigma_{G}^{2})+\frac{8Lq\eta_{s}}{mK}\sigma^{2}, G1=maxr∈𝒯s⁡‖∇F​(𝐱r)‖2subscript𝐺1subscript𝑟subscript𝒯𝑠superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑟2G_{1}=\max_{r\in\mathcal{T}_{s}}\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{r})\|^{2}, and G2=maxr∈𝒯c⁡‖1m​∑i∈[m]∑k∈[K]∇Fi​(𝐱r,ki)‖2subscript𝐺2subscript𝑟subscript𝒯𝑐superscriptnorm1𝑚subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑘delimited-[]𝐾∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑟𝑘𝑖2G_{2}=\max_{r\in\mathcal{T}_{c}}\left\|\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\sum_{k\in[K]}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{r,k}^{i})\right\|^{2}.

Remark 3.

Theorem 4 says that, by using the server-side update with an appropriately chosen q𝑞q-value, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} effectively mitigates the bias that arises from incomplete client participation. With proper probability q𝑞q, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} guarantees stationary point convergence in non-convex functions.

By choosing parameters q𝑞q and the learning rate η𝜂\eta appropriately, Theorem 4 immediately implies the following rate:

Corollary 1.

If ηs=1Rsubscript𝜂𝑠1𝑅\eta_{s}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{R}}, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} achieves an 𝒪​(1R)𝒪1𝑅\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{R}}) convergence rate to a stationary point. If we can further assume the stochastic gradient noise at server’s side σs2=𝒪​(1m​K​σ2)superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2𝒪1𝑚𝐾superscript𝜎2\sigma_{s}^{2}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{mK}\sigma^{2}) or q=Ω​(1−1m​K)𝑞Ω11𝑚𝐾q=\Omega(1-\frac{1}{mK}), 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} achieves an 𝒪​(1m​K​R)𝒪1𝑚𝐾𝑅\mathcal{O}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{mKR}}) convergence rate to a stationary point, implying a linear speedup of convergence in terms of m𝑚m and K𝐾K.

For strongly convex functions, we have the following convergence results for 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} :

Theorem 5 (Convergence Rate for 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} in Strongly Convex Functions).

Under Assumptions 3 -  5 and assume each function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i} is μ−limit-from𝜇\mu-strongly convex, if ηs≤2L+μsubscript𝜂𝑠2𝐿𝜇\eta_{s}\leq\frac{2}{L+\mu} and q≤1/(1+4​η¯μ2​(1+30​L​η¯μ​(1+2​L​η¯μ))​G3−4μ​G4(1L+μ−(L+μ)2​η¯4​L2​μ2)​G3)𝑞114¯𝜂superscript𝜇2130𝐿¯𝜂𝜇12𝐿¯𝜂𝜇subscript𝐺34𝜇subscript𝐺41𝐿𝜇superscript𝐿𝜇2¯𝜂4superscript𝐿2superscript𝜇2subscript𝐺3q\leq 1/\left(1+\frac{\frac{4\bar{\eta}}{\mu^{2}}\left(1+\frac{30L\bar{\eta}}{\mu}(1+\frac{2L\bar{\eta}}{\mu})\right)G_{3}-\frac{4}{\mu}G_{4}}{\left(\frac{1}{L+\mu}-\frac{(L+\mu)^{2}\bar{\eta}}{4L^{2}\mu^{2}}\right)G_{3}}\right), then, the sequence {𝐱r}subscript𝐱𝑟\{\mathbf{x}_{r}\} generated by 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} satisfies:

𝔼​‖𝐱R−𝐱∗‖2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝐱𝑅subscript𝐱2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\mathbf{x}_{R}-\mathbf{x}_{*}\|^{2} ≤(1−η¯)R​‖𝐱0−𝐱∗‖2+δ¯,absentsuperscript1¯𝜂𝑅superscriptnormsubscript𝐱0subscript𝐱2¯𝛿\displaystyle\leq(1-\bar{\eta})^{R}\|\mathbf{x}_{0}-\mathbf{x}_{*}\|^{2}+\bar{\delta},

where δ¯=8​q​ηc​Kμ​σG2+2​q​ηcμ​m​σ2+4​q​L​(1+K​ηc​L)μ×[5​K​ηc2​(σ2+6​K​σG2)]+(1−q)​L+μ2​L​μ​ηs​σs2¯𝛿8𝑞subscript𝜂𝑐𝐾𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺22𝑞subscript𝜂𝑐𝜇𝑚superscript𝜎24𝑞𝐿1𝐾subscript𝜂𝑐𝐿𝜇delimited-[]5𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑐2superscript𝜎26𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺21𝑞𝐿𝜇2𝐿𝜇subscript𝜂𝑠superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑠2\bar{\delta}\!=\!\frac{8q\eta_{c}K}{\mu}\sigma_{G}^{2}\!+\!\frac{2q\eta_{c}}{\mu m}\sigma^{2}+\frac{4qL(1+K\eta_{c}L)}{\mu}\times\left[5K\eta_{c}^{2}(\sigma^{2}+6K\sigma_{G}^{2})\right]+(1-q)\frac{L+\mu}{2L\mu}\eta_{s}\sigma_{s}^{2}, G3=‖∇F​(𝐱r)‖2subscript𝐺3superscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript𝐱𝑟2G_{3}=\left\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{r})\right\|^{2}, G4=1m​∑i∈Sr[Fi​(𝐱r)−Fi​(𝐱∗)]subscript𝐺41𝑚subscript𝑖subscript𝑆𝑟delimited-[]subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐱𝑟subscript𝐹𝑖subscript𝐱G_{4}=\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in S_{r}}\left[F_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{r})-F_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{*})\right], and η¯=ηc​K​μ2=2​ηs​L​μL+μ¯𝜂subscript𝜂𝑐𝐾𝜇22subscript𝜂𝑠𝐿𝜇𝐿𝜇\bar{\eta}=\frac{\eta_{c}K\mu}{2}=\frac{2\eta_{s}L\mu}{L+\mu}.

The following results immediately follow from Theorem 5:

Corollary 2.

If ηc=Ω​(l​o​g​(R)R)subscript𝜂𝑐Ω𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑅𝑅\eta_{c}=\Omega(\frac{log(R)}{R}) and ηs=Ω​(l​o​g​(R)R)subscript𝜂𝑠Ω𝑙𝑜𝑔𝑅𝑅\eta_{s}=\Omega(\frac{log(R)}{R}), 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} achieves an 𝒪~​(1R)~𝒪1𝑅\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(\frac{1}{R}) convergence rate.

Remark 4.

In the strongly convex setting, Theorem 5 shows that, with proper hyperparameters, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} achieves convergence guarantees and can effectively mitigate the impacts of incomplete client participation.

Remark 5.

We note that 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} is a unifying framework that includes two classic algorithms as special cases under two extreme settings: i) the i.i.d. client-side data case and ii) the heterogeneous client-side data case with unbounded gradient dissimilarity. In the i.i.d. case, the client-side data are homogeneous, i.e., Fi​(𝐱)=Fsubscript𝐹𝑖𝐱𝐹F_{i}(\mathbf{x})=F and σG=0subscript𝜎𝐺0\sigma_{G}=0. In this ideal setting, we can simply choose q=1𝑞1q=1 and 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} reduces to the classical FedAvg algorithm. In the heterogeneous case with unbounded gradient dissimilarity (i.e., σG→∞→subscript𝜎𝐺\sigma_{G}\rightarrow\infty), we can set q=0𝑞0q=0 (i.e., |𝒯c|=0subscript𝒯𝑐0|\mathcal{T}_{c}|=0) such that 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} reduces to the centralized SGD algorithm. In this setting, Theorem 4 and 5 recover the classic SGD bounds by cancelling the σGsubscript𝜎𝐺\sigma_{G}-dependent terms in the bound.

Remark 6.

Corollary 1 and 2 suggest that, thanks to the two “control knobs”, learning rate η𝜂\eta and q𝑞q in 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} , under mild conditions, we can avoid the limitation of conventional FL algorithms. For example, FedAvg with incomplete client participation can only converge to an error ball dependent on the data heterogeneity parameter σGsubscript𝜎𝐺\sigma_{G} (Yang et al., 2022). In SA-FL, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} with incomplete client participation can still achieve the same convergence rates as these of classic FedAvg algorithms with ideal client participation: 𝒪​(1/m​K​R)𝒪1𝑚𝐾𝑅\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{mKR}) for non-convex functions (Yang et al., 2021b) and 𝒪~​(1/R)~𝒪1𝑅\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/R) for strongly convex functions (Li et al., 2020b).

5 Numerical results

In this section, we conduct numerical experiments to verify our theoretical results using 1) logistic regression (LR) on MNIST dataset (LeCun et al., 1998), 2) convolutional neural network (CNN) on CIFAR-10 dataset (Krizhevsky et al., 2009). To simulate data heterogeneity, we distribute the data into each client evenly in a label-based partition, following the same process as in previous works (McMahan et al., 2017; Yang et al., 2021b; Li et al., 2020b). As a result, we can use a parameter p∈{1,2,5,10}𝑝12510p\in\{1,2,5,10\} to represent the classes of labels in each client’s dataset, which serves as an index of data heterogeneity level (non-i.i.d. index). The smaller p𝑝p-value, the more heterogeneous the data among clients. To mimic incomplete client participation, we force s𝑠s clients to be excluded. We can use s∈{0,2,4}𝑠024s\in\{0,2,4\} as an index to represent the degree of incomplete client participation. In our experiments, there are M=10𝑀10M=10 clients in total, and m=5𝑚5m=5 clients participate in the training in each communication round, who are uniformly sampled from the M−s𝑀𝑠M-s clients. We use FedAvg without any server-side dataset as the baseline to compare with 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} with auxiliary data size {50,100,500,1000}501005001000\{50,100,500,1000\} for MNIST and {500,5000,10000}500500010000\{500,5000,10000\} for CIFAR10. So in each dataset, we have at least 4×3×4=48434484\times 3\times 4=48 sets of experiment for ablation study. Due to space limitation, we highlight the key observations in this section, and relegate all other experimental details and results to the supplementary material.

1) Performance Degradation of Incomplete Client Participation: As shown in Table 1, a distinct and non-trivial decline in performance is observed for FedAvg when confronted with incomplete client participation. As the value of s𝑠s increases, it signifies progressively more incomplete client participation. Upon comparing scenarios with s=0𝑠0s=0 and s=4𝑠4s=4 , a significant reduction in test accuracy becomes apparent, reaching up to 27.44%percent27.4427.44\% for MNIST and 25%percent2525\% for CIFAR10. It is noteworthy that such performance degradation is also contingent on data heterogeneity, denoted by p𝑝p. In the case of IID data (p=10𝑝10p=10), only a negligible decrease in test accuracy is observed. For instance, in MNIST, the accuracy slightly drops from 92.69%percent92.6992.69\% for s=0𝑠0s=0 to 92.62%percent92.6292.62\% for s=4𝑠4s=4. In CIFAR10, the accuracy decreases from 81.12%percent81.1281.12\% for s=0𝑠0s=0 to 77.78%percent77.7877.78\% for s=4𝑠4s=4. These results empirically validate the worst-case analysis in Theorem 1 and serve as the primary motivation for the development of SA-FL.

2) Improvement of the 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} Algorithm under Incomplete Client Participation: The improvements of our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} can be observed in two aspects: improved test accuracy and faster convergence rate.

I. Improved test accuracy. In Table 2 and  3, we show the test accuracy improvement of our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm compared with that of FedAvg in standard FL. In Table 2, we can observe that even with a few server participation with a probability of 0.20.20.2, there is a non-negligible improvement in test accuracy. In Table 3, the key observation is that, with a small amount of auxiliary data at the server, there is a significant increase of test accuracy for our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm. For example, with only 505050 data samples at the server (0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the total training data), there is a 16.65%percent16.6516.65\% test accuracy increase. With 100010001000 data samples, the improvement reaches 31.07%percent31.0731.07\%. This verifies the effectiveness of our SA-FL framework and our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm. Another observation is that for nearly homogeneous case (e.g., from p=10𝑝10p=10 to p=5𝑝5p=5), there is no statistical difference with or without auxiliary data at the server (denoted by ‘-’ in Table 3. This is consistent with the previous observations of negligible degradation in cases with homogeneous data across clients.

II. Faster convergence rate. In Fig. 2, we show the convergence processes of 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} on CIFAR-10 under incomplete client participation (s=4𝑠4s=4) with non-i.i.d. data (p=1𝑝1p=1). We can see clearly that the convergence of 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} is accelerating and the test accuracy increases as more data are employed at the server.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we rigorously investigated the server-assisted federated learning (SA-FL) framework (i.e., to deploy an auxiliary dataset at the server), which has been increasingly adopted in practice to mitigate the impacts of incomplete client participation in conventional FL. To characterize the benefits of SA-FL, we first showed that conventional FL is not PAC-learnable under incomplete client participation by establishing a fundamental generalization error lower bound. Then, we showed that SA-FL is able to revive the PAC-learnability of conventional FL under incomplete client participation. Upon resolving the PAC-learnability challenge, we proposed a new 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} (server-assisted federated averaging) algorithm that enjoys convergence guarantee and the same level of communication efficiency as that of conventional FL. Extensive numerical results also validated our theoretical findings.

Impact Statement

This paper delves into the realm of federated learning, a cutting-edge paradigm in machine learning that leverages decentralized training across multiple devices while preserving data privacy. The primary objective of our research is to contribute to the advancement of federated learning methodologies, addressing challenges and exploring opportunities for enhancing model performance in a privacy-preserving manner. As with any technological innovation, our work on federated learning has many potential societal consequences, none which we feel must be specifically highlighted here.

Lemma 1 (Auxiliary Lemma (Massart & Nédélec, 2006; Koltchinskii, 2006; Hanneke & Kpotufe, 2019, 2020)).

For any m∈ℕ𝑚ℕm\in\mathbb{N} and δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), define A​(m,δ)=dℋm​log⁡(mdℋ+1m​log⁡(1δ))𝐴𝑚𝛿subscript𝑑ℋ𝑚𝑚subscript𝑑ℋ1𝑚1𝛿A(m,\delta)=\frac{d_{\mathcal{H}}}{m}\log(\frac{m}{d_{\mathcal{H}}}+\frac{1}{m}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})) With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, ∀h,h^∈ℋfor-allℎ^ℎℋ\forall h,\hat{h}\in\mathcal{H},

ℛ​(h)−ℛ​(h^)≤ℛ^​(h)−ℛ^​(h^)+c​min⁡{ℙS​(h≠h^),ℙ^S​(h≠h^)}​A​(m,δ)+c​A​(m,δ),ℛℎℛ^ℎ^ℛℎ^ℛ^ℎ𝑐subscriptℙ𝑆ℎ^ℎsubscript^ℙ𝑆ℎ^ℎ𝐴𝑚𝛿𝑐𝐴𝑚𝛿\displaystyle\mathcal{R}(h)-\mathcal{R}(\hat{h})\leq\mathcal{\hat{R}}(h)-\mathcal{\hat{R}}(\hat{h})+c\sqrt{\min{\{\mathbb{P}_{S}(h\neq\hat{h}),\hat{\mathbb{P}}_{S}(h\neq\hat{h})\}}A(m,\delta)}+cA(m,\delta), (16)
12​ℙS​(h≠h^)−c​A​(m,δ)≤ℙ^S​(h≠h^)≤2​ℙS​(h≠h^)+c​A​(m,δ),12subscriptℙ𝑆ℎ^ℎ𝑐𝐴𝑚𝛿subscript^ℙ𝑆ℎ^ℎ2subscriptℙ𝑆ℎ^ℎ𝑐𝐴𝑚𝛿\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\mathbb{P}_{S}(h\neq\hat{h})-cA(m,\delta)\leq\hat{\mathbb{P}}_{S}(h\neq\hat{h})\leq 2\mathbb{P}_{S}(h\neq\hat{h})+cA(m,\delta), (17)

Proof.

Without loss of generality, we use c𝑐c serve as a generic constant since we focus on the order in terms of the sample number and thus omit the constant factor.

A.1 Discussions

We want to cast caveats on Corollary 1. The results in Corollary 1 does not hold in arbitrary cases. Specifically, Corollary 1 requires both Rs≥4​σG2−4​G2​(12​K2−2​L​ηs2K2)(1−L​ηs)​G1​Rcsubscript𝑅𝑠4superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐺24subscript𝐺212superscript𝐾22𝐿superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑠2superscript𝐾21𝐿subscript𝜂𝑠subscript𝐺1subscript𝑅𝑐R_{s}\geq\frac{4\sigma_{G}^{2}-4G_{2}(\frac{1}{2K^{2}}-\frac{2L\eta_{s}^{2}}{K^{2}})}{(1-L\eta_{s})G_{1}}R_{c} and Rs=𝒪​(Rm​K)subscript𝑅𝑠𝒪𝑅𝑚𝐾R_{s}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{R}{mK}). Appendix B Experiments

In this section, we provide the details of the numerical experiments and some additional experimental results.

B.1 Models and Datasets

We test the 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm by running two models on two different types of datasets, including 1) multinomial logistic regression (LR) on MNIST, and 2) convolutional neural network (CNN) on CIFAR-10. Both datasets are chose from a previous FL paper (McMahan et al., 2017), and they are now widely used as benchmarks for FL research (Yang et al., 2021b; Li et al., 2020b).

MNIST and CIFAR-10 have ten classes of images separately. In order to impose the heterogeneity of the data, we partition the dataset according to the number of classes (p𝑝p) that each client contains. We distribute these data to M=10𝑀10M=10 clients, and each client only has a certain number of classes. Specifically, each client randomly selects p𝑝p classes of images and then evenly samples training and test data-points within these p𝑝p classes of images without replacement. For example, if p=2𝑝2p=2, each client only samples training and test data-points within two classes of images, which causes the heterogeneity among different clients. If p=10𝑝10p=10, each client contains training and test samples that selects from ten classes. This situation is almost the same as i.i.d. case. Hence, the number of classes (p𝑝p) in each client’s local dataset can be used to represent the level of non-i.i.d. qualitatively. In addition, to mimic incomplete client participation, we enforce s𝑠s clients to be exempt from participation, where the index s𝑠s can be used to represent the degree of incomplete client participation. Specifically, we assume there are M=10𝑀10M=10 clients in total, and m=5𝑚5m=5 clients participate in each communication round. These clients are uniformly sampled from M−s𝑀𝑠M-s clients. Larger incomplete client participation index s𝑠s means less clients participate in the training.

For both MNIST and CIFAR-10, the global learning learning rate 1.0, the local learning rate is 0.1, and the server learning rate for 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} is 0.1. The local epoch is 1. For MNIST, the batch size is 64, and the total communication round is 150. For CIFAR-10, the batch size is 500, and the total communication round is 5000. To simulate the data heterogeneity, we use p=[10,5,2,1]𝑝10521p=[10,5,2,1] as a proxy to represent the degree of non-i.i.d. on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. To emulate the effect of incomplete client participation, we set s=[0,2,4]𝑠024s=[0,2,4] to represent the degree of incomplete client participation for the 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm and the FedAvg algorithm. FedAvg is employed as the baselines to compare with our algorithm. To compare the effect of the collaboration from server, we add [50,100,500,1000]501005001000[50,100,500,1000] data to the server’s side for MNIST and [500,5000,10000]500500010000[500,5000,10000] for CIFAR-10 and choose the client update probability q=[0.4,0.6,0.8,1.0]𝑞0.40.60.81.0q=[0.4,0.6,0.8,1.0]. In the case of q=1.0𝑞1.0q=1.0, our proposed algorithm 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} is equivalent to FedAvg.

B.2 Additional Experimental Results

In Table 4, we show the comparison between our 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm and FedAvg algorithm on CIFAR-10 for incomplete client participation s=4𝑠4s=4. The observations in Section 5 are further illustrated: 1) There is non-negligible increase of the test accuracy for 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} algorithm with small amount of auxiliary data at server’s side. With 10000 data at server’s side, the test accuracy increases by 23.86 %. 2) There is actually no improvement with these auxiliary data for nearly homogeneous case (e.g., p=10𝑝10p=10), which is denoted by ‘-’ in the table.

In Table 5, we show the test accuracy of 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} on MNIST and CIFAR-10 under different client update probability q𝑞q. Note that when q=1.0𝑞1.0q=1.0, 𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨𝖲𝖠𝖥𝖠𝖱𝖨\mathsf{SAFARI} is equivalent to FedAvg. We can observe that even with a few server participation with a probability of 0.20.20.2, there is a non-negligible improvement in test accuracy.

B.4 Ablation study about Random Initializations

We have run each experiment setting with five random initializations for the MNIST dataset and three random initializations for the CIFAR10 dataset. We report the mean and standard variance. The results are summarized in the following tables, which will also be added in the revision.

B.5 Ablation Study about Number of Clients

In addition to the important roles of p𝑝p and s𝑠s, we agree that m𝑚m could serve as another influencing factor. Consequently, we have incorporated additional configurations for varying values of m𝑚m, as delineated below. From these results, it is apparent that m𝑚m has a negative effect on test accuracy in non-i.i.d. scenarios. As the non-i.i.d. degree increases, the negative influence of m𝑚m becomes more pronounced.
